Just in case anyone is here for the wrong reasons, be aware that the Hollywood view of chloroform is total fantasy…it isn’t a quick or safe inhalant anesthetic, and even with “safe” anesthesia you must have a doctor for 1:1 medical monitoring and preparation, or there is decent risk of death or serious harm (brain damage, lung damage from aspirating stomach acid/contents, etc).  If you are unconscious from anesthesia, you need someone there to constantly closely monitor your breathing, as there is a decent risk to stop breathing - which is why the film/TV knockout gas has never been made irl (see also, Michael Jackson, and Russian school hostage deaths).  There have also been multiple deaths from crimes where people tried cholorforming someone after forgetting “TV isn’t reality” and “put some on a rag” is a great way to over/up under dose someone.

What Nile red did here is known as haloform reaction and is a very interesting reaction of aldehydes/ketones and of Sodium hypo halites (NaOX). In the result you get an haloform. Here Nile reacted acetone which is propanone (a ketone) with bleach which is Sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl). This gave us Chloroform which is CHCl3. So I have many problems with the way this was done and I think this deserves a revisit video. The proper way to do this would be with a 4 neck 5L round bottom reaction vessel in an ice bath, a Jointed volumetric addition funnel, Vapor trap primed with bleach, Vacuumed pipette with stopper and mechanical stirrer. The point is efficiency and waste you are creating. The bleach can be reacted by adding 100ml per reaction to the bleach, vacuum extract the settled chloroform directly into a separatory funnel, repeating until the chlorine content is depleted or near depleted. I believe anything below 3% chlorine is where the degradation occurs. Then fractionate the chloroform cold in a rotary evaporator being careful to not bring above 72F to avoid degrading the PTFE seals.

Hey NileRed, chemist here. Love your channel and the vids. Solid work, but there is an easier way to test your molarity of sodium hypochlorite. Every chemical manufactured and sold, legally must have an SDS. Every SDS will tell you the concentration but 90% of the time it will be as a percentage, and I believe it is in section 3 (used to have to write these in college chemistry). from the percentage you can do some density and volume calculations to find the mass of sodium hydrochloride and convert to molarity. Very easy to do and the only way to do it without scientific glass. For anybody unfamiliar with an SDS, one can be found by the correct manufacturer doing a simple Google search. just make sure you're looking for the SDS of the exact chemical you possess not just a similar one.

Cheers mates!

Huh. I actually hadn't realized you can pretty much safely neutralize bleach with hydrogen peroxide, or vice-versa. That's potentially useful information when restoring plastics-- and counter-intuitive for that purpose (adding an additional whitening agent to neutralize the original one). That's potentially important, because unreacted bleach or peroxide left in the plastic can gradually make it brittle.

I suppose this is also one way to make an emergency oxygen generator, or a questionable choice if you run out of table salt.

'... and prevent the formation of phosgene.'

The reaction producing phosgene (g) ( 2CHCl3 + 2O2 --> 2COCl2 + 2H2O + Cl2) is not prevented by the addition of absolute ethanol.
The phosgene (COCl2) just reacts with the ethanol to form the less dangerous ethyl chloroformate.

This actually is a named reaction. I wonder he did not mention it. It can also be used so make bromoform or iodoform when instead of chlorine one of the other halogens is used. Therefore ts is named the "Haloform Reaction". Usually the haloform is not so interesting and the method is used to obtain the carboxylic acid from a methyl substituted keton. Another name for the reaction is "Einhorn Reaction" which is German for "Unicorn Reaction" (has nothing to do with unicorns, Einhorn is just the name the chemist, but unicorn would be the English translation of his name)

It takes at least five minutes of inhaling an item soaked in chloroform to render a person unconscious. Most criminal cases involving chloroform also involve another drug being co-administered, such as alcohol or diazepam, or the victim being found to have been complicit in its administration. After a person has lost consciousness due to chloroform inhalation, a continuous volume must be administered and the chin must be supported in order to keep the tongue from obstructing the airway, a difficult procedure typically requiring the skills of an anesthesiologist. In 1865 as a direct result of the criminal reputation chloroform had gained, medical journal The Lancet offered a "permanent scientific reputation" to anyone who could demonstrate "instantaneous insensibility" using chloroform.

When I made mine I tried stirring one of the containers. I used a screw driver b/c it was the closest object that would work. The reaction became near violent and almost behaved like a baking soda/vinegar solution while turning brown. I think the iron behaved like a catalyst. I stirred to try to get the acetone into solution between adding portions, as I added it in thirds due to lack of a 100mL or even 50mL graduated cylinder. I found it was better to add all three portions of acetone and then shake the container (it would puff slightly from the exothermic energy and then suck in due to the cold overtaking the heat initially formed). I also found that Clorox bleach gave much better yields than off brand bleach. I didn't assay the bleach before running the reaction; I just rounded down the [%] and required mL acetone to account for any variation.

It takes at least five minutes of inhaling an item soaked in chloroform to render a person unconscious. Most criminal cases involving chloroform also involve another drug being co-administered, such as alcohol or diazepam, or the victim being found to have been complicit in its administration. All these comments about using Chloroform...
Chloroform doesn't work like it does in the movies. In reality, it takes a good 5-10 minutes to knock someone out in this manner. The Lancet Medical Journal once offered a reward to anyone who could demonstrate Chloroform instantly knocking someone out. Unsurprisingly, said prize has gone unclaimed, as it is impossible to do this.
Also, using Chloroform requires an Anesthesiologist to carefully regulate the dose so as no to cause death while also supporting the tongue to stop it blocking the airway. This is a difficult procedure to get right, even for a trained anesthesiologist. The whole Chloroform Cliche is a load of crap.

Use of chloroform as an incapacitating agent has become widely recognized, bordering on clichéd, due to the popularity of crime fiction authors having criminals use chloroform-soaked rags to render victims unconscious. However, it is nearly impossible to incapacitate someone using chloroform.[36] It takes at least five minutes of inhaling an item soaked in chloroform to render a person unconscious.

Most criminal cases involving chloroform also involve another drug being co-administered, such as alcohol or diazepam, or the victim being found to have been complicit in its administration. After a person has lost consciousness due to chloroform inhalation, a continuous volume must be administered and the chin must be supported in order to keep the tongue from obstructing the airway, a difficult procedure even for an anesthesiologist.

I was reading a very old book, "Traité de Chimie Industrielle (1903)".
They were making chloroform in industrial quantities with alcohol and calcium chloride. I suppose CaCl2 was cheap then, because it was a by-product of the Solvay process.
Their recipe, make a solution with 4 parts of lime chloride and 3 parts of 96% alcohol in 13 parts of water.
Heat slowly to 40C, then 50C, then 60C with thorough mixing.
Now distill at a low temp. The first fraction is pure chloroform, then a mix of chloroform and alcohol, then alcohol, then water and alcohol.
According to the text, to get 1kg of chloroform, you use 1Kg of alcohol but 13 Kg of calcium chloride.

Next is a recipe to make chloroform with acetone and calcium chloride. This one has a much better yield, and give a more pure end product. 1Kg of acetone gives 1.73Kg of chloroform with that method. In the first phase, the acetone is refluxed with the calcium chloride until it is entirely converted to chloroform, which is then distilled.

The crude chloroform is then dried with calcium chloride, washed with sulfuric acid, washed with an alcaline solution, then dried again with calcium chloride. No word about adding a small quantity of ethanolto the end product to avoid the formation of very toxic phosgene.

A lot of people are commenting that they got very low yields with the procedure; I generally get about 70% for mine. The first and most important tip is that you absolutely must cool the bleach to a very, very low temperature! It is perfectly acceptable to freeze your bleach solid! Secondly, you must not let the reaction mixture sit for too long, because the side products of the reaction will actually begin to eliminate the chloroform over time. You will also get a low yield if you are impatient and don't let the reaction occur for long enough. I let mine sit for about 6-10 hours(overnight) and from a gallon of 8.25% bleach I usually get 75-100mL, as seen here: http://vignette2.wikia.nocookie.net/sciencemadness/images/d/d9/Chloroform%21.JPG/revision/latest?cb=20140830023303

I'm always vexed by bleach in home science projects, especially concentrated bleach, created from electricity put through salt water. Bleach is essentially sodium hypochlorite suspended in water (I believe). More concentrated forms exist in swimming pool chlorine often called chlor 5 and concentrations seem to max out at 15% in general circulation though this seems to be chlorine bleach made by mixing chlorine and caustic soda (sodium hydroxide) in otherwords, a different active ingredient.

Which is the 'active ingredient' we're really after when we go to our household bleach for science experiments? I ask so I buy a product to give a higher yield.
